Only three inputs are read
Input type is double instead of int
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reusing a template from a different physics/kinematics problem and not adjusting the input handling to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompt to request five integers, and use nextInt (in a loop or five times) to read the five integer values.

misconceptions.name: Implements average acceleration formula instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program computes and prints the average acceleration based on v0, v1, and t instead of summing the even numbers among five user-entered integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the required output is the average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should accumulate the sum of only the even numbers among the five input integers and print that sum with an appropriate message.
symptoms: Output message refers to 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
Calculation uses (v1 - v0) / t rather than summing selected inputs
No accumulator variable or even-number filtering is present
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between this assignment and a different exercise about physics formulas, leading to copying the wrong solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the average acceleration calculation with logic that iterates over the five inputs, checks if each is even, adds even values to a sum, and then prints 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire main method is tailored to an unrelated physics problem and lacks any constructs for summing even numbers.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The average acceleration is %f", (v1 - v0) / t);
evidence.note: The printed message and formula correspond to average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code solves a completely different, standard physics/programming problem (average acceleration) and shares no functional resemblance with the required solution (sum of 5 even numbers).

evidence.note: This block of code is entirely dedicated to solving an average acceleration problem, not the required sum of even numbers problem.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misalignment - wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student has written code to solve a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration given v0, v1, and t) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers from 5 integers). This is a fundamental misunderstanding or misreading of the requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem about acceleration rather than a problem about filtering and summing even integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, identifying which are even (divisible by 2), and printing their sum. The expected output for input '3 8 2 7 4' is 'Sum of even numbers: 14' (since 8 + 2 + 4 = 14).
symptoms: Code prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Output calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure for processing 5 inputs
No modulo operator (%) or conditional logic for even number checking
No accumulator for sum calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the problem statement or copied code from a different assignment without properly understanding the actual requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem requirements. You need to: (1) create a loop that runs 5 times, (2) read one integer each iteration, (3) check if each is even using (n % 2 == 0), (4) add even numbers to a running sum, (5) print the final sum with the label 'Sum of even numbers:'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is absolutely clear - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem. There is no code present that attempts the required task at all.

evidence.note: This entire program calculates physics acceleration, not sum of even integers. No attempt to read 5 integers or identify even numbers.
